questions.question: Although the movie was interesting, I couldn't enjoy it. Here interesting is a/an ..........................................
questions.description: Here interesting acts as a subject complement.

questions.question: It is a burning issue. Here burning is a/an ...................................
questions.description: Here burning is an adjective because it modifies the noun issue.

questions.question: The students are preparing for their exam. Here preparing is a/an ......................................
questions.description: Here preparing is used to form the present continuous tense form. Hence it is a participle.

questions.question: We are waiting to hear from them. Here waiting is a/an .........................................
She is an interesting writer. Here interesting is a/an ......................................
questions.description: Here interesting modifies the noun writer. Hence it is an adjective.

questions.question: The dog was chasing the cat. Here chasing is a/an ......................................
questions.description: It helps form the past continuous tense form.

questions.question: A rolling stone gathers no moss. Here rolling is a/an .......................................
questions.description: Here rolling modifies the noun stone. Hence it is an adjective.

questions.question: The hawkers were shouting at the top of their voice. Here shouting is a/an ........................................
questions.description: It helps form the past continuous tense form were shouting.

questions.question: The news was shocking. Here shocking is a/an ........................................
questions.description: Here shocking acts as a subject complement.

questions.question: The man was standing on the table. Here standing is a/an .....................................
questions.description: It helps form the past continuous tense form.

questions.question: There was not even standing room on the bus. Here standing is a/an .......................................
questions.description: Here standing modifies the noun room hence, it is an adjective.

questions.question: The story was confusing for me. Here confusing is a/an .........................................
She was excited about the project.
questions.description: Excited is an adjective here and it acts as the complement of the verb was.

questions.question: I watched an interesting movie yesterday.
questions.description: When ing forms are used before nouns they act as adjectives.

questions.question: She was driving us crazy.
questions.description: When ing forms are used to form continuous tenses, they are used as participles.

questions.question: I hope you are fully recovered from your operation.
questions.description: Recovered is an adjective here. Participles are often used after the verb be. In this case, they complete the predicate and act as adjectives.

questions.question: Her idea seems exciting.
questions.description: Participles are often used as adjectives after be and other copular verbs.

questions.question: The children were screaming at the top of their voice.
questions.description: When ing forms are used to form continuous tenses, they act as present participles.

questions.question: I had warned you.
questions.description: When participles are used to form perfect tenses, they act as past participles.

questions.question: He was not expecting this.
questions.description: When participles are used to form continuous tenses, they act as present participles.

questions.question: It was beginning to rain.
questions.description: When ing forms are used to form continuous tenses, they act as present participles.

questions.question: I did not enjoy the party because I was bored.
questions.description: Participles are often used after the verb be as adjectives. In this case, they complete the verb.

questions.question: They have not been able to find the missing child.
questions.description: When ing forms are used before nouns, they act as adjectives.

questions.question: She is retired now.
questions.description: Participles are often used after the verb be as adjectives. In this case, they complete the verb.
